author: usmarine2141
body:
I downloaded a ps1 module and i am not able to import the module into. Can you provide steps to import. below is what i am attempting to import for testing.

https://github.com/dafthack/MailSniper

<!--

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->
## Steps to reproduce
## Expected behavior
## Actual behavior
## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable

```

comments.author: Jaykul
comments.body:
That's a script (.ps1) not a module (.psm1). 

Either dot-source it, to import the functions to your current scope:

``` posh
. .\MailSniper.ps1
```

Or rename it to .psm1 and then `import-module .\MailSniper.psm1`

comments.body:

comments.author: usmarine2141
comments.body:
if i am in the directory and do the following i get this

PS /root/MailSniper> ./MailSniper.psm1  
PS /root/MailSniper> 

PS /root/MailSniper> Import-Module ./MailSniper.psm1  
PS /root/MailSniper>

comments.author: usmarine2141
comments.body: Disregard. I got it to work now. Sorry for the trouble!

comments.author: EkremSel
comments.body: @usmarine2141 Im having the same trouble. I got it to work when i cd into the directory. But other than than it does not recognize it.

comments.author: kilasuit
comments.body:
@EkremSel - you need to be in the directory where this is downloaded for you to be able to import scripts into your session which is a standard behaviour (since PowerShell v1)
 
The exception to this is if you have a PowerShell Module in one of the paths that is in the PSModulePath environmental variable then you can call `Import-Module <Module Name>`

comments.body:
